I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The Rural Enterprise Financing Project will increase incomes of subsistence small farmers 
by helping them engage in rural enterprises. Through Small Farmers Development Bank (SFDB) 
(the financial intermediary) and SFDB’s member small farmers agriculture cooperatives (SFACs), 
the project will finance rural enterprises comprising (i) collective enterprises that are jointly owned 
and operated by small farmers, and (ii) individual enterprises.1 The project will also improve the 
financial  intermediary’s  rural  enterprise  financing  capacity  as  well  as  provide  value  chain 
development and business facilitation support for small farmers, especially women. 
 
2.  The project is aligned with the following impact: employment-oriented economic activities 
increased.2 The project will have the following outcome: small farmers’ engagement in rural 
enterprises increased. The project has three outputs: (i) collective enterprises developed and 
financed, (ii) individual enterprises promoted and financed, and (iii) rural enterprise financing 
capacity enhanced. The project will be financed with $50 million loan from the concessional 
ordinary capital resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Although Nepal has made notable socioeconomic progress since 1995, poverty is still 
rampant in rural areas. Of Nepal’s total population of 29 million, 23 million (81%) live in rural areas; 
of this rural population, an estimated 6 million (27.4%) live below the poverty line.3 Nepal’s rural 
poverty is largely due to the limited gainful employment opportunities. In rural Nepal, agriculture 
is the main source of livelihood. However, the agriculture sector is largely subsistence in nature 
and  confined  to  primary  production  of  crops  and  livestock  with  little  value  addition  and 
commercialization. The average landholding per household is 0.7 hectares and the majority 
(51.6%) of farm households have landholding of less than 0.5 hectares.4 In terms of per capita 
consumption, the average Nepali spent NRs80,807 in 2017; during the same year, the average 
urban consumption was NRs103,146 and the average rural consumption was NRs64,701.5 The 
earnings from agriculture activities are hardly enough for rural households to move out of poverty. 
 
4.  To reduce rural poverty, it is necessary to shift from current subsistence production to 
value-adding rural enterprises. A value chain in agriculture is a set of activities that adds value to 
commodities  and  links  primary  producers  to  processers,  traders,  merchants  with  storage, 
transport, processing, packing, marketing, and financing. To add value to their primary production, 
some households have started value chain enterprises or rural enterprises, both on-farm and off-
farm, such as commercial crop production and processing of agricultural produce.6 However, rural 
enterprise development is hampered because of insufficient business facilitation and limited rural

enterprise financing. Developing rural enterprises in Nepal requires various support, including 
business facilitation, capacity building, and financing. 
 
5.  For rural enterprise financing, microfinance institutions (MFIs) can be a major source of 
finance because of their strong presence in rural areas and their long association with rural 
communities. However, MFIs face various challenges in enterprise financing, including (i) a 
regulatory ceiling on MFIs’ loans of NRs1 million, (ii) MFIs’ limited sources of funding, and (iii) 
MFIs’ limited knowledge and capacity in rural enterprise financing. To address rural enterprises’ 
financing and capacity constraints, the project will provide loans to rural enterprises through 
SFDB, an apex cooperative bank, and its member SFACs. In addition to financing, SFDB will 
extend value chain development and business facilitation support to SFACs and their members 
to promote investment-ready rural enterprises. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  The attached technical assistance (TA) will support SFDB and SFACs to enhance their 
capacity in rural enterprise financing and extend rural enterprise value chain development and 
business facilitation support. The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6); and (ii) $250,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Special Fund.7 SFDB will 
provide counterpart contribution equivalent to $30,000 in the form of office space, counterpart 
staff, logistical support and other in-kind contributions. Disbursement will follow ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be 
implemented over 5 years. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  Consulting services. ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s South Asia Department will 
select, supervise,  and evaluate  the  consultants.  ADB  will  recruit  international  and  national 
consultants using individual consultant selection. ADB will procure consulting services following 
the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the staff instructions for 
ADB-administrated consultants. The required consultant inputs are as follows: (i) international 
value chain product development and marketing specialist (4 person-months, intermittent); (ii) 
international agribusiness finance specialist (international, 3 person-months, intermittent); (iii) 
national assistant to the project implementation unit director (26 person-months, intermittent); (iv) 
national  value  chain  development  specialist  (36  person-months,  intermittent);  (v)  national 
agribusiness finance specialist (36 person-months, intermittent); (vi) national environmental and 
social safeguards specialist (10 person-months, intermittent); and (vii) national gender specialist 
(6 person-months, intermittent).8  
 
9.  Procurement of goods and non-consultancy services. Procurement of goods and non-
consultancy services, if any, will be procured by following procedures explained in the staff
